title: 108_hr1345
content: The "Equity for Reservists Pay Act of 2003" ensures that federal employees serving on active duty in a reserve component of the uniformed services do not have their pay reduced. The "Equity for Reservists Pay Act of 2003" guarantees that federal employees who are also members of a reserve component and are called to active duty for more than 30 days will receive the difference between their civilian pay and military compensation during that period. The "Equity for Reservists Pay Act of 2003" ensures federal employees called to active duty for over 30 days receive military compensation for each pay period, including hospitalization or convalescence periods. The "Equity for Reservists Pay Act of 2003" ensures federal employees called to active duty receive military compensation equivalent to civilian basic pay, paid by the employing agency from appropriate funds, and in consultation with the Office of Personnel Management and the Secretary of Defense for necessary regulations. The "Equity for Reservists Pay Act of 2003" mandates agencies to establish procedures ensuring employee rights under the act. The Federal Aviation Administration must also implement these procedures. Definitions for terms like 'active duty' and 'civilian basic pay' are provided in the section. An employee entitled to payments means the agency with reemployment rights under chapter 43 of title 38. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in title 5, United States Code. Section 5538 of title 5, United States Code, ensures nonreduction in pay for those serving on active duty in a reserve component. The amendment applies to pay periods starting after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, assistance is provided to state and local governments that continue to pay employees serving in a reserve component of the uniformed services. Section 910 of title 37, United States Code, encourages state and local governments to continue paying employees who are also members of a reserve component and are called to active duty for more than 30 days. The purpose is to ensure that these employees receive compensation equal to their civilian pay when combined with their military pay. Reimbursement is offered to governments that continue to pay a portion of the civilian compensation. The Secretary concerned shall reimburse the State or local government for 50 percent of the civilian compensation paid for each pay period, not exceeding 50 percent of the difference between civilian and military pay for employees on active duty. Reimbursement rate increases to 100 percent for pay periods extending over nine consecutive months after the employee's active duty begins. Reimbursement is provided for the difference between civilian compensation and military pay for the interrupted period. Reimbursement is provided for each pay period during active duty, hospitalization, or convalescence. Failure to return to employment may result in loss of reimbursement. If an employee fails to report or apply for employment with the government after a certain period, they must refund the reimbursement received. The obligation to refund is considered a debt to the United States, but the Secretary may waive it under certain circumstances. Bankruptcy does not discharge the employee from this debt within five years. The section outlines regulations for debts arising from employment with the government, including definitions for terms like civilian compensation, local government, and military pay.
